descendants.content:
@inkynibs this is a story either told poorly, or used inappropriately to shift blame. A number of tree killing boring #beetles have devastated huge tracts of forests across North America, creating huge #wildfire risk as #ClimateChange increases #drought. This is compounded by regional #Forestry practices of reducing competing understory with desired species to create monocultures (using #Glyphosate and other methods). It is an enormous problem that gets little coverage.
https://www.ctif.org/news/modern-forestry-practices-may-be-partly-blame-north-american-wildfire-crisis

There is this romantic old steam train puffing up to the Brocken peak.
But, what a picture. At least the valley is still green.

account.note:
🌏 Born at 312 PPM

Retired NGO executive doing my best to stay informed and raise awareness about environmental crises, climate breakdown, and the rapacious, murderous impact of greedy capitalists and the politicians they own.

Why the name? Back in the day, empires placated their citizens with "bread and circuses." Now we get fast food and apps. But it's all basically the same — distraction from what's REALLY happening.

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses @inkynibs
There is a wild discussion going on about the reasons, with some even blaming "green management" for the breakdown. Because supposedly the bugs are being "protected", which sounds like alternative facts to me.

There are, as very often, many reasons: storm, drought, fire, bugs, forest mismanagement, greed...

Some say that the bugs are only a symptom, not the cause.

descendants.content: @angstlotse @breadandcircuses I'm not sure about the situation in Germany; but in northern Alberta, the mountain pine beetle is not protected, and its proliferation is enhanced by climate change. The combination of drought, causing water stress in the trees, short-sighted forestry practices, and beetle infestation, kills huge swathes of forest, setting up perfect conditions for wildfire.

descendants.content: @inkynibs @breadandcircuses I think that the suggested "beetle protection" is just a gaslight or a bent truth to blame the national park management. Mostly, pines have been grown here for quicker profit. The beetles just eat those profits I guess. The area here just looks like it needs a couple dry weeks and a spark.

descendants.content: @angstlotse @breadandcircuses Like I said, you don't need to be a wildfire expert to foresee the obvious. Besides, it really doesn't matter if the beetle is protected; that much standing deadwood near any settlement is a recipe for disaster.

descendants.content:
@inkynibs Combine that with extreme heat and lightning strikes.

Drought provides a smorgasbord for the beetles. The tree’s primary defense for the beetle is to “pitch them out” but the trees need moisture to create enough resin/sap to fend them off. And when there are large populations of beetles that attack a tree, with high success rates causing whole tree mortality.

account.note:
Nursing & Law, RN, JD. I've worked in the U.S. for-profit healthcare system for many years and I firmly believe healthcare must be a human right for all.

Army Brat. Avid reader and teller of stories. Burner of sage. Artist. Mom of two daughters. Currently living in Southern California.

I care passionately about the environment and the climate crisis. Fascinated by the intertwined politics of nature and power.

*Left Twitter to join Democracy Town April 2022* The Fediverse Rocks!!
